facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 957 of 1964 was filed in the Supreme Court.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated January 12, 1963 of Judicial Commissioners Court, Himachal Pradesh in Civil Misc. 2nd Appeal No. 15 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated January 12, 1963 of the Judicial Commissioners Court. Himachal Pradesh in Civil Misc. 2nd Appeal No. 15 of 1961.

facts.text: Himachal Pradesh State legislature passed the Himachal Pradesh Abolition of Big Landed Estates and Land Reforms Act 1953 on June 17, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The Himachal Pradesh State legislature passed the Himachal Pradesh Abolition of Big Landed Estates and Land Reforms Act 1953  hereinafter referred to as the Act  on June 17, 1953

facts.text: The Act was brought into force with effect from January 26, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: and the Act was brought into force with effect from January 26, 1955.

facts.text: Validity of the Act was successfully impugned in Shri Vinod Kumar v. State of Himachal Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: The validity of the Act was thereafter successfully impugned  cf. Shri Vinod Kumar v. State of Himachal Pradesh  1 .

facts.text: Parliament passed the Validating Act, 56 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The Parliament then passed the Validating Act, 56 of 1958.

facts.text: Validating Act challenged in Jadab Singh v. Himachal Pradesh Administration but challenge rejected.

anchor.surface_text: That Act was itself then challenged in Jadab Singh v. Himachal Pradesh Administration  2   but the challenge was rejected

facts.text: Respondent made application under s.11 of the Act on June 4, 1959 for acquiring proprietary rights in lands.

anchor.surface_text: On June 4, 1959 the respondent made an application under s. II of the Act for acquiring proprietary rights in the lands set out therein

facts.text: Respondent claimed to be cultivating tenant of Union of India in respect of the said lands.

anchor.surface_text: claiming to be the cultivating tenant of those lands and produced a companyy of Jamabandhi in support of his claim.

facts.text: Respondent paid Rs. 35/5/- annually as rent and Rs. 23/8/- as annual land revenue and other rates and cesses.

anchor.surface_text: that he was paying Rs. 35/5/- annually as rent and Rs. 23/8/- as annual land revenue and other rates and cesses assessed on the said lands

facts.text: Forest Department on behalf of Union filed objections on November 26, 1959 alleging lands part of protected forest, no landlord-tenant relation.

anchor.surface_text: On November 26, 1959 the Forest Department on behalf of the Union filed objections alleging that the application was incompetent, that the said lands formed part of the protected forest.

facts.text: Objections included that there were trees on the lands and respondent was merely a lessee.

anchor.surface_text: that a number of trees stood on the said lands, that the respondent was merely a lessee of the said lands which were a forest area,

facts.text: Compensation Officer held area not forest, no trees, respondent occupancy tenant entitled to proprietary rights, fixed compensation Rs. 76.40.

anchor.surface_text: The Compensation Officer held, that the said area was number a forest area, that there were numbertrees on the said lands as alleged and that since the respondent was mentioned as an occupancy tenant

facts.text: Forest Department appealed to District Judge, Mahasu on procedural grounds.

anchor.surface_text: The Forest Department there upon filed an appeal before the District Judge, Mahasu. principally on the ground that the Compensation Officer had number followed the procedure

facts.text: District Judge allowed appeal and remanded case on July 26, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: On July 26, 1960 the District Judge allowed the appeal and remanded the case to the Compensation Officer

facts.text: Forest Department did not dispute in appeal that respondent held lands as tenant of Government.

anchor.surface_text: The Forest Department did number dispute in the said appeal that the appellant held the said lands as a tenant of the Government.

facts.text: After remand, Compensation Officer again held respondent tenant, no impediment, allowed application.

anchor.surface_text: The Compensation Officer held that the respondent was a tenant, there was numberimpediment in granting proprietary Tights to  him and allowed once again the respondents application.

facts.text: District Judge dismissed appeal, held respondent tenant of Union and Act applies.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal by the Union against the said order before the District Judge failed. The District Judge held that the respondent was ,the tenant of the Union

facts.text: Union filed Second Appeal before Judicial Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: The Union filed a Second Appeal before the Judicial Commissioner challenging the companyrectness of the District Judges said order.

facts.text: Judicial Commissioner dismissed Union's appeal on January 12, 1963, holding Act binds Union by necessary implication.

anchor.surface_text: In that view he dismissed the Unions appeal.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal filed after certificate under Art. 133(1)(c).

anchor.surface_text: The Union of India filed this appeal after obtaining certificate under Art. 133 1  c  of the Constitu- tion.

He held that on a consideration of the relevant provisions of the Act the conclusion to which I have been driven is that by necessary implication the Act binds the Government and an application under section I I of the Act by a tenant is competent in respect of land held by him under the Government.
